(c) Discharge characteristic of Li–O2 batteries at the current density of 0.05mA/cm2 and (d) various current densities. Reproduced from Ref. [57] with permission from The Royal Society of Chemistry. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) SEM image of a VA-NCCF array grown on a piece of Si wafer by CVD. (b) TEM image of an individual VA-NCCF. (c) The sketch of Li2O2 grown on a coral-like carbon fiber. [73]. Copyright (2014) Amercican Chemical Society. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) TEM image of Ir-rGO composite, showing Ir nanoparticles less than 2nm in size. The circle in (a) shows some small Ir atomic clusters. Scale bars: 2nm. (b) Voltage profiles of the Ir-rGO cathode. Cycle number of voltage plot is given by the color of the plotting symbol. Inset shows capacity as a function of cycle number. (c) Schematic showing lattice match between LiO2 and Ir3Li that may be responsible for the LiO2 discharge product found on the Ir-rGO cathode. Reprinted from Ref. [92] with permission from Nature Publishing Group. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a,b) TEM images and (c) SAED patterns of the Co3O4 NF/GNF composite. (d) Initial charge/discharge curves and (e) cycle performance of different electrodes at a current density of 200mA/g. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [103]. Copyright (2013) Amercican Chemical Society. Fig 6 Fig. 7 (a) HRTEM images of Co@NC. The inset shows the (111) crystal plane of the Co particle. (b) Discharge/charge profiles of the Li–O2 batteries with different cathodes at a current density of 200mA/g with the fixed capacity of 2000 mAh/g. (c) Calculated free energy diagram for the oxygen electrode reactions on the surface of Co@NC. (d) A schematic representation of the oxygen reaction process using Co@NC based oxygen electrode for Li–O2 batteries. (e) Cycling stability and the terminal discharge voltage as a function of cycle number for the graphene, CNTs and Co@NC based cathodes for Li–O2 batteries. Reprinted from Ref. [142] with permission from Elsevier. Fig 7 Table 1 Summary of carbon-based materials and their hybrids for Li-O2 batteries. Tel: +86 0592 2186917 Rechargeable lithium-oxygen (Li–O2) batteries have been considered as the most promising candidates for energy storage and conversion devices because of their ultra high energy density. Until now, the critical scientific challenges facing Li–O2 batteries are the absence of advanced electrode architectures and highly efficient electrocatalysts for both oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), which seriously hinder the commercialization of this technology. In the last few years, a number of strategies have been devoted to exploring new catalysts with novel structures to enhance the battery performance. Among various of oxygen electrode catalysts, carbon-based materials have triggered tremendous attention as suitable cathode catalysts for Li–O2 batteries due to the reasonable structures and the balance of catalytic activity, durability and cost. In this review, we summarize the recent advances and basic understandings related to the carbon-based oxygen electrode catalytic materials, including nanostructured carbon materials (one-dimensional (1D) carbon nanotubes and carbon nanofibers, 2D graphene nanosheets, 3D hierarchical architectures and their doped structures), and metal/metal oxide-nanocarbon hybrid materials (nanocarbon supporting metal/metal oxide and nanocarbon encapsulating metal/metal oxide). Finally, several key points and research directions of the future design for highly efficient catalysts for practical Li–O2 batteries are proposed based on the fundamental understandings and achievements of this battery field. Graghical abstract Image, graphical abstract Nanocarbon-based materials with numerous unique properties and reasonable structures, have been identified as promising oxygen electrode catalysts for non-aqueous Li–O2 batteries. Keywords Electrocatalysis Electron transfer Lithium–oxygen batteries Nanocarbon materials 1 Introduction To minimize the consumption of fossil fuels, and thereby reduce CO2 emissions which consequent effects on global warming, an indispensable strategy to electrification of road transportation is now underway. The major technical hurdle confronting complete electrification transformation is the exploration of advanced energy storage systems [1,2]. Lithium-ion battery technology has established itself as a promising and reliable energy storage system over the past 20 years. While after continuous development, the energy density of Li-ion battery system increased ≈15% per year and may reach the theoretical limits soon, which may severely limit the range of electric vehicles. Therefore, a novel battery chemistry beyond the prevailing Li-ion battery technology is urgently needed to develop the next generation of electrical energy storage systems [3–5]. Due to the extremely high specific capacity (3860mAh/g) and the low reduction potential (−3.04V vs standard hydrogen electrode, SHE), metallic lithium is the most promising anode material for high energy density batteries [6–8]. Furthermore, low-cost O2 from the atmosphere reacts directly with the shuttled Li+ ions in the porous electrode, resulting in a greatly increased theoretical specific energy. Because of the especially high theoretical gravimetric energy of 3500Wh/kg, that far outperforms that of other available battery chemistries, Li–O2 battery chemistry has triggered tremendous attention as a promising candidate to conventional Li-ion batteries [9–11]. Generally, four categories of Li–O2 batteries are designated by the type of the electrolyte employed in batteries: non-aqueous, aqueous, hybrid, and all-solid-state batteries. Because of the insufficient ionic conductivity of solid-state electrolyte and parasitic corrosion on Li metal anode of aqueous electrolyte, the non-aqueous electrolyte has dominated research efforts on Li–O2 batteries compared to the other electrolyte-based Li–O2 batteries [12–14]. In order to avoid the contaminants (such as H2O or CO2) from air, most Li-air batteries are operated in pure oxygen, so it is expressed as “Li–O2 batteries” rather than “Li–air batteries”. A typical non-aqueous Li–O2 battery (Fig. 1 ) consists of a metallic lithium anode, a separator saturated with Li+ conducting organic electrolyte, and a porous cathode. The cathode electrochemical pathway is based on the reversible redox reaction: 2Li+ +2e− +O2↔Li2O2 (E 0 = 2.96V vs Li/Li+). During the discharge process, O2 is reduced (oxygen reduction reaction, ORR) in the porous structure of the cathode, and consequent combined with the shuttled Li+ ions to form insoluble and insulated Li2O2 products, which will sluggishly decompose to release O2 (oxygen evolution reaction, OER) in the following charge process. The slow reactions occurring in the cathodes give rise to a large voltage gap (usually large than 1V) between the charge and discharge of a Li–O2 battery, resulting in a much lower round-trip efficiency of < 60% compared to the commercial Li-ion battery (> 90%). A number of strategies have been devoted to reducing the severe hysteresis between charge and discharge, such as the regulation of temperature [15–17], employment of redox mediator [18–23] and ionic liquid [24–29], as well as the solar integrating [30,31]. Despite much achievements have been made, Li–O2 battery technology is still at its infant stage. Before the commercial application of this technology, fundamental questions such as Li dendrites, poor rate capability, low round-trip efficiency, electrolyte and carbon degradation and poor cyclability should be resolved. Among various factors affecting Li–O2 battery performance, the lack of superior catalytic activity with novel structures of the oxygen cathode catalysts have been considered as the vital point. In the last few years, numerous oxygen cathode catalysts have been proposed to reduce the large voltage gap, including noble metals, transition-metal oxides, and carbonaceous materials. Due to the reasonable structures and the balance of catalytic activity, durability and cost, carbon-based materials have been considered promising as suitable cathodes for rechargeable Li–O2 batteries. In this review, the discussions and insights provided reflect the most recent approaches and directions for carbon-based oxygen electrocatalysts (including nanostructured carbon materials and metal/metal oxide-nanocarbon hybrid materials) developments (Table 1 ). In addition, we also review the status and challenges and provide a perspective of oxygen electrocatalysts for non-aqueous Li–O2 batteries. 2 Nanostructured carbon catalysts Due to the chemically tailorable surface, high specific surface area, high porosity, excellent electrical conductivity and low cost, nanostructured carbon materials have been considered as promising alternatives of oxygen electrodes for non-aqueous Li–O2 batteries. The carbon materials can fabricate a continuous porous structure in order to accommodate discharge products and provide channels for ions transfer and oxygen diffusion, they can also act as electrocatalysts towards ORR as well as OER in non-aqueous Li–O2 batteries. In this section, the peculiar carbon nanostructures are summarized as four main groups: one-dimensional (1D) carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and carbon nanofibers (CNFs), 2D graphene nanosheets, 3D hierarchical architectures and their doped structures. 2.1 Carbon nanotubes and nanofibers Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have recently been investigated as cathode materials for non-aqueous Li–O2 batteries because of their high chemical and thermal stability, high conductivity, high tensile strength and large surface area [32–41]. A novel carbon air electrode with controlled pore structure by Lim et al. [32]. The air electrode was fabricated by orthogonally plying individual sheets of aligned multi-walled nanotubes (MWNTs) without use of any binder or solvent. The unique porous framework in these woven CNT electrodes significantly improved the cyclability of the Li–O2 battery. This was attributed to the facile accessibility of oxygen to the inner side of the air electrode, and preventing the clogging of pores by the discharge product (Li2O2). Even at an extremely high current density (2000mA/g), the battery can still maintain at least 60 cycles with a fixed capacity of 1000mAh/g. Similarly, another new type of porous carbon electrode architecture was proposed by Mitchell et al. [42]. Vertically aligned arrays of hollow carbon fibers with diameters on the order of 30nm were grown on a porous alumina substrate, as shown in Fig. 2 (a, b). At a current rate of 43mA/gC, Li–O2 batteries with CNFs discharged at an average voltage of 2.6V over the entire discharge process (Fig. 2c). The all carbon fiber electrodes can deliver gravimetric energies up to 2500Wh/kgdischarged at powers up to 100W/kgdischarged (Fig. 2d). To suppress undesirable side reactions between the carbon electrode and electrolyte or active intermediates (such as O2 − and O2 2−) by preventing their direct contact, Lee et al. [36] put forward a simple surface modification strategy by applying a polyimide coating to CNTs, the obtained cathode showed excellent cycling performance, without significant loss of capacity. Recent study proposed by Yoo et al. showed that carbon related air electrode can also provide low overpotential for OER process of Li–O2 battery using double lithium salt LiNO3-LiTFSI/DMSO system [43]. The charge potential of the Li–O2 battery using MWCNTs electrode was around 3.61V at the capacity of 1000mAh/g. And the battery with MWCNTs can undergo around 90 cycles without obvious losses of capacity with a fixed capacity of 1000mAh/g at the current rate of 500mA/g. 2.2 Graphene nanosheets Graphene is a two-dimensional (2D) crystal consisting of a one-atom-thick of sp 2-hybridized carbon. Since Geim and Novoselov first exfoliated single-layer graphene from highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) in 2004, a wide range of applications on this novel material have surged with the merits of its intrinsically superior thermal and electrical conductivity, large surface area, remarkable mechanical flexibility, and high mobility of charge carriers [44–51]. Recently, because of the high discharge capacity and superior round-trip efficiency, graphene has been employed as a promising cathode material for non-aqueous Li–O2 batteries [52–54]. Li et al. [53] firstly employed graphene nanosheets (GNSs) as oxygen electrode for non-aqueous Li–O2 batteries. The cathode based on GNSs delivered an excellent electrochemical performance with a high discharge capacity (8705.9mAh/g) at a current density of 75mA/g, which was much higher than that of the cathodes with commercial carbon materials of BP-2000 and Vulcan XC-72 (1909.1 and 1053.8mAh/g, respectively). Although the detailed mechanism for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) on GNSs in the non-aqueous electrolyte is unclear, this work revealed that this unique morphology of GNSs can provide promising applications in Li–O2 batteries. At the same time, Sun et al. [54] also applied GNSs as cathode catalysts for Li–O2 batteries with alkyl carbonate electrolyte. In comparison to the commercial Vulcan XC-72 electrode, the GNSs electrode exhibited better cyclability and lower overpotential due to the presence of carbon vacancies and defects on GNSs surface. 2.3 Hierarchical architectures Because of the insoluble and insulated discharged products of Li2O2, which accumulate at the active sites of the oxygen electrode during discharge, potentially clogging the pores and consequently leading to the failure of batteries, it is imperative to develop the porous structures and the hierarchical architectures of the oxygen electrode for high performance of non-aqueous Li–O2 batteries. Accordingly, significant efforts have been devoted to optimizing the structure of the oxygen electrode. Xiao et al. [55] designed a novel hierarchically porous oxygen electrode with functionalized graphene sheets (FGSs) that contains lattice defects and functional groups by a colloidal microemulsion approach. This unique hierarchical morphology consists of numerous large tunnels facilitating continuous oxygen diffusion, while other interlaced nanoscale pores providing ideal tri-phase regions with abundant reactive sites for the oxygen reactions. DFT calculations also revealed that the defects and functional groups on graphene nanosheets favor the formation of isolated nanosized Li2O2 particles, which can ensure facile oxygen diffusion during the discharge process and help prevent oxygen blocking in the oxygen electrode. This oxygen electrode design shines light on how to control the architecture and surface chemistry of the carbon-based electrode for rechargeable Li–O2 batteries. Based on this insight, a number of strategies have been devoted to improving the performance of Li–O2 batteries [56–63]. A free-standing hierarchically porous carbon (FHPC) derived from graphene oxide (GO) gel had been proposed by Wang et al. [56] to maximize the utilization of porous carbon particles, which facilitated a continuous oxygen flow and also provided enough void volume for Li2O2 accommodation. When employed as a cathode, the Li–O2 battery simultaneously exhibited a high specific capacity (11,060mAh/g at a current density of 280mA/g) and excellent rate capability. Lin et al. [57] prepared hierarchically porous honeycomb-like carbon (HCC) as the oxygen electrode for Li–O2 batteries (Fig. 3 a,b), the obtained HCC-based cathode delivered a higher specific capacity of 3233mAh/g, which is more than three times that of Super P (Fig. 3c). Due to the larger BET surface area, larger pore volume and increased number of defects, HCC-100 sample with smaller diameter pores showed a better performance than HCC-400 with larger pores according to the initial discharge capacity and cycling performance (Fig. 3d). Guo et al. [61] used 3D ordered mesoporous-macroporous carbon sphere arrays (MMCSAs) as the cathode catalyst for high performance Li–O2 batteries. The ordered mesoporous channels could effectively improve the electrolyte immersion and facilitate Li+ diffusion and electron-transfer process. Moreover, these macropores, surrounded by ordered mesoporous channels in the structure, could provide sufficient space for Li2O2 accommodation/decomposition and O2 diffusion. 2.4 Doped carbon materials Carbon materials doped with heteroatoms (such as N, B, P or S) can tune the chemical and electronic nature of carbon-based materials [64–66]. Many efforts have demonstrated that doping heteroatoms can increase the degree of defectiveness, which act as the active sites for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in aqueous electrolyte [67–71]. Based on this insight, Li et al. [72] firstly used N-doped GNSs for Li–O2 batteries, and found that by nitrogen doping could introduce more defects and functional groups, leading to a higher ORR catalytic activity than that of pure GNSs. After that, doping carbon materials have been widely used as an effective cathode catalyst of Li–O2 batteries [34,62,73–79]. Dai's group [73] demonstrated that vertically aligned nitrogen-doped coral-like carbon fiber (VA-NCCF) arrays can act as a metal-free cathode catalyst for Li–O2 batteries (Fig. 4 a–c). The VA-NCCF electrode exhibited a discharge capacity as high as 40,000mAh/g and ran for more than 150 cycles under a limited capacity of 1000mAh/g at the current density of 500mA/g (Fig. 4e). The voltage gap between the discharge and charge plateaus at a current density of 100mA/g was only 0.3V (Fig. 4d). The obtained excellent battery performance can be attributed to the nitrogen dopants which induced the catalytic activity of carbon fiber to lower the charging overpotential, and the unique porous structure that provided a large free space for Li2O2 accommodation and enhanced electron/electrolyte/reactants transport. Theoretical calculation has also applied to understand the ORR/OER processes using heteroatoms doping graphene-based cathode catalysts for non-aqueous Li–O2 batteries and provide useful insight into the catalyst design [80–83]. Yan et al. [83] carried out DFT calculations towards oxygen adsorption and dissociation on the graphene and N-doped graphene surfaces. They found that charge transfer between the O2 molecule and the graphene sheet can make the adsorption energetically stable. Upon N-doping, the adsorption of oxygen atoms can be enhanced, and the energy barrier of O2 dissociation can decrease from 2.39eV (undoped case) to 1.20eV. Jiang et al. [80] systematically investigated the feasibility of graphene, N-doped, B-doped and N, B co-doped graphene as the potential catalysts in non-aqueous Li–O2 batteries. Their results showed that B-doped graphene exhibits the lowest discharge and charge overpotentials. While co-doping of N and B atoms does not have synergistic effects to enhance the ORR/OER catalytic activity in the presence of lithium atoms, which can significantly change the most stable adsorption site and adsorption energy in ORR/OER process, leading to the obstruction of electron transfer between oxygen atoms and the substrates. 3 Metal/metal oxide-nanocarbon hybrid catalysts Metals especially noble metals have been widely used as effective electrocatalysts to facilitate electrochemical reactions (including ORR/OER and HER) based on their superior electrocatalytic activity and high stability [84,85]. However, due to their heavy molecular weight and the scarce reserves, which lead to low energy density and high cost of batteries, nanocarbon materials as the lightweight and porous substrates have been extensively introduced into cathodes of Li–O2 batteries to address the problems. 3.1 Nanocarbon supporting metals/metal oxides To achieve lower charge overpotential and higher round-trip efficiency, there has been a universal strategy to construct composite electrode catalysts by loading metals or metal oxides, which act as the catalytic active structures, on graphene and other carbon materials. Up to now, most of the research on precious metal based composites focused on Ru [63,86–90], Pt [89–91], Ir [92], Au [89,91], and Pd [89,90,93–95]. Lu et al. [91] have systematically investigated the catalytic activity of Pt and Au on ORR and OER in Li–O2 batteries. They found surface Pt atoms were catalytically effective towards OER while Au atoms were responsible for ORR. In order to exert both merits, they combined Au and Pt on Vulcan XC-72 support, the PtAu/C hybrid catalyst demonstrated the low charging voltage and high round-trip efficiency of Li–O2 batteries. The OER catalytic activities of noble metals such as Pt, Pd, Ru supported on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) in Li–O2 battery cathodes have been systematically investigated by Sun's group [90]. All the noble metals explored could lower the charge overpotentials, and among them, Ru-rGO hybrid exhibited the lowest charge overpotential and the most stable cycling performance without electrolyte decomposition, whereas Pt- and Pd-rGO hybrids showed fluctuating potential profiles and electrolyte instability during cycling. Most recently, Lu et al. [92] reported a stable one-electron process that forms LiO2 without conventional Li2O2 as the only discharge product using a suitable Ir-rGO cathode in Li–O2 batteries (Fig. 5 ). This one-electron process that LiO2 formed can maintain stable during cycling with a very low charge plateau (about 3.2V). They proposed a novel templating growth mechanism that Ir3Li intermetallic compound with an orthorhombic lattice may be responsible for the growth of crystalline LiO2 by the results of TEM and DFT calculations. This significant discovery will lead to methods of synthesizing and stabilizing LiO2, which could open up a way to high-energy-density Li–O2 batteries based on one-electron process. Quite different from the precious metals, the studies on non-precious metals used in Li–O2 batteries are rarely reported, probably because of their readily oxidation exposing in oxygen atmosphere during battery operation. Kwak et al. [96] prepared FeCo bimetal nanoparticles coating on CNTs as an efficient catalyst in both ORR and OER for Li–O2 battery. The charge potential of FeCo-CNTs (3.89V) is lower than that of CNTs (4.31V) with the capacity limitation of 1000mAh/g at the rate of 100mA/g. Apart from the nanocarbon-metal composite catalysts mentioned above, functional carbon based metal oxides composite have been widely investigated as oxygen electrocatalysts for Li–O2 batteries. Noble metal oxide especially ruthenium oxide (RuO2) [97–101] can serve as an excellent OER catalyst in Li–O2 batteries. Yin et al. [98] proposed a binder-free and self-standing hierarchical macroporous active carbon fiber (MACF) electrode via a facile and scalable strategy. With RuO2 decorating (R-MACF), the specific capacity of the R-MACF cathode can reach as large as 13,290mAh/g even at a high current rate of 1000mA/g, which is higher than those of 11,150, 6810, 5307 and 1737mAh/g for MACF, CNTs, macroporous active carbon (MAC) and active carbon fibers (ACFs), respectively. Even after 29 cycles, the charge overpotential using R-MACF cathode was as low as 0.66V, with the energy conversion efficiency of 78%. In consideration of the scarcity and high cost of noble metals, transition-metal oxides have dominated most of the research on Li–O2 batteries, including single-metal oxides and multi-metal oxides [102–114]. Among different single-metal oxides, manganese oxides and cobalt oxides are the most extensively studied catalyst for Li–O2 batteries. Ryu et al. [103] proposed 1D Co3O4 nanofibers immobilized on both sides of the 2D nonoxidized graphene nanoflakes as an efficient oxygen electrode catalyst for Li–O2 batteries (Fig. 6 a–c). The catalyst exhibited a high discharge capacity of 10,500mAh/g at the current density of 200mA/g and stable cyclability for 80 cycles (Fig. 6d,e). This excellent performance was mainly attributed to the improved bifunctional catalytic activity of Co3O4 nanofibers for both ORR and OER, and the large surface area which could provide sufficient space for easy O2 diffusion and facile electron transport. Multi transition metal oxides with spinel [110–112,115], perovskite [113,116–119], or pyrochlore [120] structure are widely used as excellent ORR and OER electrocatalysts for Li–O2 batteries. The transition-metal atoms have been substituted by other metal atoms in these multi-metal oxides, modulating the electronic structure which can contribute to the catalytic activity for ORR/OER. Wang et al. [110] employed MnCo2O4-graphene hybrid material as the cathode catalyst. This uniformly distribution of oxide nanoparticles on graphene substrate showed an excellent catalytic activity, leading to lower overpotentials and longer lives of Li–O2 batteries than other catalysts including noble metals such as platinum. Xu et al. [116] firstly employed perovskite-based porous La0.75Sr0.25MnO3 nanotubes (PNT-LSM) as an excellent oxygen electrocatalyst in nonaqueous Li–O2 batteries. Compared to the conventional Ketjenblack (KB) carbon cathode, the mixed PNT-LSM/KB could significantly suppress the ORR and especially OER overpotentials and thus improve the round-trip efficiency. Furthermore, the battery with a high specific capacity, superior rate capability and good cycle stability can be attributed to the synergistic effect of the high catalytic activity and the unique hollow channel structure of the PNT-LSM catalyst. 3.2 Graphene encapsulating metals/metal oxides Non-precious metals have been widely studied as promising alternatives to noble metals in many catalytic redox reactions [121–126]. While, some catalytic reactions usually carried out under harsh conditions such as strong acid or base, oxidation and high temperature, the exposed non-precious metal catalysts cannot be stable in these harsh environments, leading to the deactivation of catalysts. How to protect the non-precious metals from deactivation and maintain their intrinsic activities in the harsh atmosphere turned into a challenging and significant point to design low-cost catalysts. Different from aforementioned prevalent approach, Deng et al. [127] proposed a novel strategy to encapsulate a series 3d transition metals (TMs) within graphene layers, converting the carbon surface into the active sites for catalytic reactions due to the electron transfer from the internal metals. This penetrated electron can increase the density of states (DOS) of graphene around the Fermi level and decrease the local work function of the graphene surface, resulting in a significantly enhanced catalytic activity. More importantly, owing to the protection of the graphene “chainmail”, the metal nanoparticles can effectively avoid the corrosion and poisoning without direct contacting with the solutions, reaction molecules or poisons during reaction. This “chainmail” construction strategy has been widely investigated in different catalytic systems including fuel cells [128–132] and water electrolysis [133–137], triiodide reduction reaction (IRR) in dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) [138,139], and other heterogeneous catalytic oxidation and reduction reactions [140,141]. Moreover, reducing the layer number of graphene matrix and introducing the heteroatoms (such as nitrogen) into the graphene matrix will significantly promote the electron transfer thus enhance the catalytic activity. It was found that N-doped single-layer graphene encapsulating FeNi alloys showed excellent activity and durability of electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction (OER), even exceeding that of a commercial IrO2 catalyst. According to the concept of 2D crystal 'chainmail' for catalysts, Tu et al. firstly systematically investigated the nitrogen-doped single layer graphene shell encapsulating non-precious metals (M@NC) as the highly efficient catalysts for Li–O2 batteries (Fig. 7 a) [142]. The Co-based catalyst (Co@NC) showed significantly enhanced OER catalytic activity, with a charge overpotential of 0.58V, which was remarkably lower compared with the corresponding N-free graphene encapsulating metal, metal oxide and metal-free carbon materials (Fig. 7b). Moreover, the Co@NC based electrode showed a better cycling performance than graphene and CNTs based electrodes (Fig. 7e). DFT calculations revealed that the nitrogen dopants and enclosed metal clusters can synergistically modulate the electronic properties of the graphene surface, resulting in a dramatic reduction of the overpotentials (Fig. 7c, d). Similar configurations have also been applied to noble metals/metal oxides. Recent study by Huang et al. [89] found that the encapsulation of noble metal nanoparticles (Pd, Pt, Ru and Au) inside end-opened CNTs by wet impregnation followed by thermal annealing, can significantly strengthen the electron density of the carbon surface, serving the entire surface of carbon shells as catalytic active regions for Li2O2 accommodation and decomposition, thus effectively reducing the high charge overpotential. Notably, the charge overpotential can be as low as 0.3V when Pd-CNTs sample is used as the cathode. Guo et al. [97] indicated that although RuO2 nanoparticles were completely within graphene and broken off the direct contact with the electrolyte and Li2O2, the encapsulated nanoparticles still showed high catalytic activities toward oxygen reactions. These works provide a novel electrode design platform on how to control the electronic structure and surface chemistry of the carbon-based electrodes for high efficiency Li–O2 batteries by enhancing the ORR as well as OER kinetics. 4 Conclusion and outlook Li–O2 batteries are becoming one of the most promising energy storage and conversion technologies for applications that require high-energy density. Although substantial progress has been made in the past few years, rechargeable non-aqueous Li–O2 batteries are still investigated on a lab-scale, further fundamental understanding of oxygen reaction (involving ORR and OER) mechanisms during battery operation, parasitic reaction mechanisms of electrolyte/electrode reacting with the highly active intermediates, and the dynamic transportation information of electron and lithium ions are the key points to explore new catalysts with novel architectures for highly efficient and long-life Li–O2 batteries. Rational design and development of chemically stable and reversible oxygen electrodes as well as the catalysts is indispensable needed to improve the performance of Li–O2 battery. Precise control over the structural and electronic properties of the surface and interface of catalysts, which efficiently affects the adsorption and desorption of the intermediates during reaction processes that closely related to the performance of batteries, can be a most promising mean to improve the energy conversion efficiency. The electrochemical reactions in Li–O2 batteries involve the diffusion of oxygen and the precipitation of discharge products. The porous structure and the catalyst distribution in the oxygen electrode require careful optimization to realize the rapid mass transportation of all reactants and electrolyte wetting. Carbon materials suffer corrosion challenges at the high operation potentials upon charging in the high concentration oxygen atmosphere of Li–O2 batteries. Recently, it has been demonstrated that carbon is unstable upon charging above 3.5V in the presence of Li2O2, undergoing oxidative decomposition to form Li2CO3 [144]. In this regard, the carbon supported catalysts and the corresponding composites with optimized porous structure and uniform catalysts distribution are worthy of further optimization in terms of both catalytic activity and stability. In-situ techniques, as well as the theoretical calculations, can directly probe and predict the oxygen electrochemical reaction processes that occurred at the surface or interface of the catalytic materials, which are quite vital for in-depth understanding of fundamental electrochemical reaction mechanisms of Li–O2 batteries. Using in situ SERS and DEMS can detect the tri-phase reaction products and intermediates, as well as elucidate the origins of parasitic reactions of electrolyte/electrode reacting with intermediates upon battery operation. Moreover, in situ TEM can reveal significant details into the accommodation and decomposition of Li2O2 on the active sites of catalysts with high spatial and temporal resolution observations. In addition, theoretical calculations have been developed quickly in the field of Li–O2 battery, but there still remains a big gap between the results of calculations and realistic reaction processes. Combining the fundamental understanding of reaction mechanisms and cutting edge computational techniques that closed to realistic conditions with materials innovation can guide us to rationally design stable and efficient catalyst for practical rechargeable Li–O2 battery. The key points of the future design for a high efficient catalyst for practical Li–O2 batteries should be summarized as follows: (1) Low cost and non-precious bifunctional electrocatalysts for both ORR and OER are required. Electrocatalysts should not only promote the formation/decomposition of discharge products, but also suppress the side reactions which seriously affect the cycling stabilities of the batteries. Moreover, exploring a suitable electrocatalysts that can stabilize one-electron process to form LiO2 as the only discharge product is also a promising strategy for Li–O2 batteries. (2) The electrocatalysts should not only significantly lower the overpotentials, but also improve the capacities, as well as stabilities of the batteries. (3) Since the 3D structures can provide abundant space for accommodation and decomposition of the discharge products and electrolyte immersion, as well as mass transfer process. Electrocatalysts with advanced 3D architecture or uniformly loaded on 3D interlaced skeleton is preferred. References [1] Z. Yang J. Zhang M.C. Kintner-Meyer X. Lu D. Choi J.P. Lemmon J. Liu Chem. coredata.dc:description: Rechargeable lithium-oxygen (Li–O2) batteries have been considered as the most promising candidates for energy storage and conversion devices because of their ultra high energy density. Until now, the critical scientific challenges facing Li–O2 batteries are the absence of advanced electrode architectures and highly efficient electrocatalysts for both oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), which seriously hinder the commercialization of this technology. In the last few years, a number of strategies have been devoted to exploring new catalysts with novel structures to enhance the battery performance. Among various of oxygen electrode catalysts, carbon-based materials have triggered tremendous attention as suitable cathode catalysts for Li–O2 batteries due to the reasonable structures and the balance of catalytic activity, durability and cost. In this review, we summarize the recent advances and basic understandings related to the carbon-based oxygen electrode catalytic materials, including nanostructured carbon materials (one-dimensional (1D) carbon nanotubes and carbon nanofibers, 2D graphene nanosheets, 3D hierarchical architectures and their doped structures), and metal/metal oxide-nanocarbon hybrid materials (nanocarbon supporting metal/metal oxide and nanocarbon encapsulating metal/metal oxide). Finally, several key points and research directions of the future design for highly efficient catalysts for practical Li–O2 batteries are proposed based on the fundamental understandings and achievements of this battery field.

coredata.dc:title: Nanocarbons and their hybrids as catalysts for non-aqueous lithium–oxygen batteries
